Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Molecular Interfaces in Fluids and Materials Warsaw, Poland on June 18-21, 2014, at Warsaw University

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal seeks support for U.S. participants to attend a four-day Workshop on "Molecular Interfaces in Fluids and Materials," to be held in Warsaw, Poland, on June 18-21, 2014, at Warsaw University. The proposed Workshop is a follow-up to and builds upon four earlier Workshops held in Poznan (2006), Gdansk (2008), Krakow (2010) and Poznan (2012). The funds will support 18 U.S. participants with emphasis on participation of junior researchers,in addition to a balance between mid-career and senior
participants.

The workshop will cover both experiment and theory. Emerging researchers and their students from throughout Poland will participate in the meeting, thereby providing a forum for interactions with US-based scientists. The Workshop is intended to provide an effective forum for discussion between researchers from the US and Poland who are working in the area of interfacial phenomena.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The VI US-Poland Workshop was held at the University of Warsaw, in Warsaw, Poland, from June 11 to June 13, 2014. The Organization Committee included Juan de Pablo (University of Chicago), Igal Szleifer (Northwestern University), Malgorzata Sliwinska-Bartkowiak (Poznan University), and Andrzej Sikorski (University of Warsaw). The meeting was attended by 26 US-based participants, and 35 Polish participants.  A distinctive feature of this sixth rendition of the conference was an emphasis on engaging young investigators from the US Five assistant or newly tenured professors, as well as four US-based graduate students, were invited to present their work at the meeting.

Those who attended the US-Poland Workshop in Warsaw found the workshop beneficial and productive.  “The workshop hosted an outstanding group of top researchers working broadly in the area of soft matter, from both the US and Poland”, said Scott Shell of UCSB.  “The organization of the meeting ensured relatively short, potent talks that greatly facilitated the exchange of ideas and the participation of a relatively large number of presenters”.  Igal Szleifer, Professor at Northwestern University, shared his thoughts as a previous organizer of a US-Poland workshop, “This is the third of the US-Poland workshop that I attended; I was the organizer of the previous one, and the quality of the scientific exchanges keeps improving.”  The discussions greatly benefited Grzegorz Szamel at Colorado State University, “The US-Poland workshop covered the whole field of complex fluids, allowing me to interact with both US and Polish scientists outside my exact area of current interest.  It allowed me to meet people I would have never met at conferences I typically attend.”

Other participants were just as impressed at the opportunity for discussion and collaboration.  According to Mark Stevens, from Sandia National Laboratories, “Being able to discuss the work of ion dynamics with an international audience brought new questions to me as well as exposing my new ideas to them.”  

The collaboration between attendees and scientists also made impacts on the careers of some attendees.  “The workshop benefitted my career by exposing me to new ideas from experts in fields other than my own…it was refreshing.”   Many attendees were excited to be able to present at the workshop.  Lisa Hall, a new Assistant Professor from Ohio State, shared her thoughts, “A benefit to my career was that I was given an invited talk and allowed to discuss my recent research results.  In general, the science presented at the meeting was very relevant to me and I had several interesting discussions about my research which increased my understanding of where I can best contribute in this area”.

Scott Shell of UC Santa Barbara shared the following experience: “I had many great discussions with Polish researchers, both research-related and informal during the meeting.  It was the first time that I have interacted on a substantial level with soft-matter scientists in Poland, and I was very excited that I had the chance to do so.”

 Arthi Jayaraman, with the University of Delaware, also found the opportunity invaluable.  She explained “I got an opportunity to discuss polymer simulations and polymer brush physics with Andrey Milchev during the breaks.  Considering that Milchev has been active in the area of polymer brushes, I found our time together extremely valuable”.  Pawel Krys, a young PhD student from Carnegie Mellon University stated, “I found the discussions with the students to be particularly useful, as they provided some really useful insights on the laboratory techniques that can be used for particular research applications.”  

According to Rong An, a student from North Carolina State University, “At my advisor’s suggestion, I came to this workshop with some questions.  Professor Matyjaszewski of Carnegie Mellon University and Professor Joan Brennecke’s with the University of Notre Dame were extremely helpful in answering some of my questions.  Prof. Brennecke did forward me her powerpoint from her presentation and I enjoyed her work.”  The discussions between attendees, helped create a collaborative environment and the opportunity for relationship building and sharing of information going forward.  Many attendees left with the plan to reconnect with those they had met.  “I had discussions with Professor Ustinov from St. Petersburg about our common interests on adsorption in porous materials.  I plan to visit Professor Ustinov next summer.”

The location of the workshop allowed some attendees to visit other local scientists.  For example Joan Brennecke, from Notre Dame, was able to visit the laboratory of Professor Urszula Domanska in the Department of Chemistry at Warsaw Technical University, just down the street from the workshop. 

Overall, the US-Poland Workshop was a huge success.  Information was gathered, shared and relationships were built with the expectation of continuing the affiliations.  It is hoped that this workshop will continue in the future, creating awareness of other’s contributions and sharing findings with those in similar fields of study.
